entry.title: Fall at Nvidia
entry.content: Congratulations to Lizi Zhang for joining Nvidia for a Fall co-op.
entry.summary: Congratulations to Lizi Zhang for joining Nvidia for a Fall co-op.

entry.title: New paper on carbon-aware distributed inference

link.title: New paper on carbon-aware distributed inference

entry.content: Our NSF-sponsored research, CADI, was presented at IEEE COINS in Madison, Wisconsin. This work explores distributing inference across a source and a partner edge device connected to different power grids, aiming to minimize the overall carbon footprint. It introduces a carbon footprint model for distributed inference that integrates computation, communication, and the hold time of partnering edge devices. An optimization formulation is proposed to determine how inference tasks should be distributed across these devices based on the carbon footprint model. Congratulations to the first author Robert Viramontes.
entry.summary: Our NSF-sponsored research, CADI, was presented at IEEE COINS in Madison, Wisconsin. entry.title: COINS panel
entry.content: Prof. Davoodi participates in an IEEE COINS 2025 panel along with Dr. Mandy Pant from Intel, and Prof. Bhuvana Krishnaswamy from UW-Madison.
entry.summary: Prof. Davoodi participates in an IEEE COINS 2025 panel along with Dr. Mandy Pant from Intel, and Prof. Bhuvana Krishnaswamy from UW-Madison.

entry.title: Robert defends and wins WISL award

link.title: Robert defends and wins WISL award

entry.content: Congratulations to Robert Viramontes for successfully defending his PhD on 5/7/2025. Robert’s disseration won the Wisconsin Initiative for Science Literacy (WISL) Award for Communicating PhD Research to the Public. (News coverage)
entry.summary: Congratulations to Robert Viramontes for successfully defending his PhD on 5/7/2025. Robert’s disseration won the Wisconsin Initiative for Science Literacy (WISL) Award for Communicating PhD Research to the Public. (News coverage)

entry.title: Summer at Cadence
entry.content: Congratulations to Lizi Zhang for starting a summer internship with Cadence.
entry.summary: Congratulations to Lizi Zhang for starting a summer internship with Cadence.

entry.title: Richard Newtorn Young Student Fellowship
entry.content: Congratulations to Navid Nader Tehrani for winning a DAC’25 Richard Newton Young Student Fellowship. The fellowship covers full registration to attend Design Automation Conference at San Francisco in June and an award of $500 to cover travel costs.
entry.summary: Congratulations to Navid Nader Tehrani for winning a DAC’25 Richard Newton Young Student Fellowship. The fellowship covers full registration to attend Design Automation Conference at San Francisco in June and an award of $500 to cover travel costs.

entry.title: Robert’s new paper and travel award

link.title: Robert’s new paper and travel award

entry.content: New paper “FreDDI: Frequency-Driven DNN Partitioning in Distributed Inference” to appear in proceedings of SMARTCOMP’25. This work formulates distributed inference in deep neural networks (DNNs) when considering frequency selection of an edge/hub/cloud device as an additional knob of control which can impact the global latency and/or energy. Congratulations to first and only student author Robert Viramontes! He has also received a $2000 NSF travel award to present his work at Cork Ireland, June 16-19.
entry.summary: New paper “FreDDI: Frequency-Driven DNN Partitioning in Distributed Inference” to appear in proceedings of SMARTCOMP’25. This work formulates distributed inference in deep neural networks (DNNs) when considering frequency selection of an edge/hub/cloud device as an additional knob of control which can impact the global latency and/or energy. Congratulations to first and only student author Robert Viramontes! He has also received a $2000 NSF travel award to present his work at Cork Ireland, June 16-19.

entry.title: Best Paper Candidate at DATE’25
entry.content: Our paper titled “ReBERT: LLM for Gate-Level to Word-Level Reverse Engineering” has been nominated for best paper in DATE’2025. Congratulations to first author Lizi Zhang and thanks to our industry collaborator Dr. Rasit Topaloglu. This paper discusses an effective way to encode a a gate-level circuit given in a Hardware Description Language to reverse engineer the higher-level words using Large Language Models. We combine different embedding schemes to encode circuit information to best be inferred by the BERT model. This includes a novel tree-based positional embedding scheme to encode the position of each gate within the graph structure of a circuit as a token sequence.
entry.summary: Our paper titled “ReBERT: LLM for Gate-Level to Word-Level Reverse Engineering” has been nominated for best paper in DATE’2025. Congratulations to first author Lizi Zhang and thanks to our industry collaborator Dr. Rasit Topaloglu. This paper discusses an effective way to encode a a gate-level circuit given in a Hardware Description Language to reverse engineer the higher-level words using Large Language Models. We combine different embedding schemes to encode circuit information to best be inferred by the BERT model. This includes a novel tree-based positional embedding scheme to encode the position of each gate within the graph structure of a circuit as a token sequence.

entry.title: Lizi’s travel award
entry.content: Congratulations to Lizi Zhang for winning a $1000 travel award to present his paper at MLCAD’24.
entry.summary: Congratulations to Lizi Zhang for winning a $1000 travel award to present his paper at MLCAD’24.

entry.title: New paper on AI for better ATPG

link.title: New paper on AI for better ATPG

entry.content: Paper accepted in IEEE/ACM Symposium on Machine Learning for CAD on effective use of neural networks for automatic test pattern generation (ATPG) in VLSI. Neural networks are used to reduce the number of backtracks when searching the decision tree of test patterns, and reduce the runtime of ATPG. Our results show neural networks are not effective if applied for backtracing in circuit nodes which are too close to, or too far away from, the inputs. We also propose a look-up technique to reuse previously-computed inferences to significantly accelerate the runtime. The neural network itself should not be too complex because of the associated inference overhead, and overall objective to reduce the runtime of ATPG. Congratulations to first (and only student) author Lizi Zhang. He will present his work in Snowbird Utah in September 2024. A version of this paper also appeared in Int’l Workshop on Logic & Synthesis in June 2024.
entry.summary: Paper accepted in IEEE/ACM Symposium on Machine Learning for CAD on effective use of neural networks for automatic test pattern generation (ATPG) in VLSI. The neural network itself should not be too complex because of the associated inference overhead, and overall objective to reduce the runtime of ATPG.
